comment._content: i believe this is one of the most outstanding spirit photographs, but i can't pass by these set without thinking of the Harry Price/William Hope controversy and the way their surnames really fit both their roles in it. while Price brought down-to-earth arguments regarding these shots, and at the same time implicitly underlining Hope's value as an artist and of his clever mind, William's shots (beside his personal benefits) definitely brought some hope in many lives. --- www.photography-news.com

comment.author: 21061284@N05
comment._content: Search William Hope. He was one of the premiere spirit photographers of the early Twentieth Century and was considered by believers and supporters to be a true master of the art of producing spirits on ordinary photographic plates. To others, he was a clever trickster and while he had more than his share of detractors, he was often accused of fraud but was never caught at it -- thanks to the controversy that surrounded the main attempt to expose him.

comment.author: 22168774@N05
comment._content:
To be fair, let's take a look at what the evenhanded Dr. Nandor Fodor wrote about Hope in his singularly exhaustive "Enclopaedia of Psychic Science." (University Books): "Hope, William (1863-1933), the best-known modern spirit photographer, a carpenter of Crewe, whose psychic power was discovered accidentally about 1905. He and a comrade photographed each other on a Saturday afternoon. The plate which Hope exposed showed an extra figure, a transparent woman, behind whom the brick wall was visible. It was the sister of Hope's comrade, dead for many years. With the help of Mr. Buxton, the organist at the Spiritualist Hall at Crewe, a circle of friends was formed to sit for spirit photography. For fear of being accused by devout Catholics to be in league with the devil, the circle destroyed all the original negatives until Archdeacon Colley came on the scene. He tested Hope's powers, endorsed them and gave him his first stand camera which Hope refused to give up long after it had become old fashioned, its box battered and its leg broken. The first hubbub about Hope and his psychic photographs arose in 1908 in connection with Archdeacon's Colley's first sitting. He recognised his mother in the psychic extra. Hope thought it was more like a picture he had copied two years earlier. Mrs. Spencer, of Nantwich, indeed, recognised her grandmother in it, after Hope took it to her. Hope informed Archdeacon Colley of his mistake. He said it was madness to think that a man did not know his own mother and advertised in the Leamington paper asking all who remembered his mother to meet him at the rectory. Eighteen persons selected the photograph from several others and testified in writing that the picture was a portrait of the late Mrs. Colley who had never been photographed. The second case of controversy arose in 1922 and was, on the surface, damning for Hope. In a report published in the Journal of the Society for Psychical Research he was accused of imposture by Mr. Harry Price. The accusations were later published in a sixpenny pamphlet. The basis of the revelation was that Mr. Price, in a sitting at the British College of Psychic Science, caught Hope in the act of substituting the dark slide, holding the exposed pates, by another; further that he (Hope) handed him two negatives (one of which contained a psychic extra) that did not bear the secret mark of the Imperial Dry Plate Company specially impressed on the packet of films by X-rays and which were different in colour and thickness from the original plates. Subsequent investigation proved that the counter-accusation raised by spiritualists of an organised conspiracy against Hope deserved examination. The wrapper of the packet was found, and it bore marks of tampering. Moreover, one of the original marked plates was returned anonymously and undeveloped to the S.P.R. a week after the experiment and three weeks before the revelation. On being developed it showed an image. As the packet of marked plates was lying about for four weeks in the office of the S.P.R. it was open to tampering and substitution, it being also likely, in the view of the Hope-apologists, that the abstractor sent back the missing plate out of pure mischief. Immediately after the revelation Hope offered new sittings and declared his willingness to submit himself to stringent tests. The offer was refused. Harry Price, however, signed a statement to the effect that the test of February 24, 1922, 'does not rule out the possibility that Hope has other than normal means.' Indeed, no less authority than Sir William Crookes bears out the true mediumship of William Hope in an authorised interview published in Christian Commonwealth on December 4, 1918. On his own marked plates, under his own conditions, he obtained a likeness of his wife different from any he possessed. On the other hand Sir Oliver Lodge was emphatic in stating concerning a test of his own with a sealed packet sent to Hope: 'I have not the slightest doubt that the envelope including the plates had been opened.' Again Sir William Barrett claimed to have received with Hope 'indubitable evidence of supernormal photography.'"
The entry by Dr. Fodor goes on many more paragraphs, all of it fascinating. Nandor Fodor, PhD., was a Hungarian-born lawyer-cum-journalist who lived at various times in Hungary and the United States. He was sympathetic of the fledgling work of psychoanalysis and psychiatry and got approval after a fashion from Sigmund Freud himself, while catching flak from spiritualists who had no time for psychological interpretations of psychic phenomena. Fodor also was at times bent on exposing frauds. His overall survey of Hope seems to be on the side of the authenticity of these photographs, hard or impossible as that might be to accept for all debunkers who, no doubt, will not be swayed one whit by this. I include this long quotation, however, for those who are open to all kinds of honest research.

comment.author: 25364395@N04
comment._content:
Well, its interesting to note Pete- that Spirtuality/Psi phenominea and Psychological study should be a the time in conflict with each other.. 

previous to that the Spritualist, Medium or Psychic healer had to be the closest thing to a psychoanalyst you had previous to the studies of Freud and Jung--

Thank you for posting the history there, I firmly believe that anyone who looks deeper into anything will be influenced by their own system of thought, you need not believe anything though to understand that sometimes what seems to be simple can be rather complex even if this be just as many people believe to be a simple case of double exposure-- many times, these things show up for a reason, and not because someone was trying to manipulate someone or get publicity. 

Even with the idea that this was a case of simple "double exposure" one has to take into account the syncronistic factors.. the timing and the odds that such a thing should happen.. by accident.. its all too easy to dismiss the past "spirit photos" as simple manipulation, simple double exposures and even fraud. I don't wish to believe in anything other than reasoning and yet sometimes the things we all come in contact with is far beyond that of normal reasoning, even today. People do not wish to even talk about these things, so why and what would be the reasoning behind faking such things? From the perspective of the past, and too often the lable of "heratic" or "devil worship".. as means to keep silent, people such as my self are often inclined to believe that the logical solution is that this is by accident and possibly the motive of the spirits, due to the fact that many people are often too scared by what they see to talk much about it, and that these phenomae are often more common than one thinks (now and in the past) just based upon the fact that there are so many silent witnesses to things out there, where as there are always people who wish to keep this information secret and use the fears of people as tool to keep the information about these things SILENT.

I always like it when someone at least draws their conclusions from study rather than simple knee jerk reaction of "It can't be real -otherwise that would mean something else is out there that I am not allowed to believe in.".

comment.author: 13375439@N06
comment._content:
HOW TO MAKE A GHOST PHOTO
1. Put 2 negatives in the plate holder, one of the 2 old people and one of the younger woman
2.  then expose them simultaneously to make the print.

It really is "child's play". (for anyone with even a rudimentary knowledge of photogrpahic wet printing).

This is exactly how it would look, and believe me with a bit more care it could have been done far more convicingly.

So why should anyone accept this as a picture of a ghost?!

Too logical for all you "sensitives" I suppose!

comment.author: 22168774@N05
comment._content:
Nobody is saying this couldn't be done, AjanProvacateur, and your point is well-taken.  However, "set and setting" and the fact that intellectual giants like Conan Doyle supported the photographer suggest that scoffing might be a bit premature.

A face to resemble a dead loved one is not "child's play" to manipulate, particularly pre-Photoshop Era.

comment.author: 9003948@N05
comment._content:
It's a bloody double exposure you mugs!!!!
For heavens sake, it's not even a good fake. The only interesting thing about this picture is how it highlights that people are as gullible now as they were then.

comment.author: 22168774@N05
comment._content: I sense your frustration, Mr. Flett, but things are not always so cut and dry.  Yes, it looks purely like a double-exposure, but if you read the history of spirit photography written by extremely intelligent and curious investigators, it is not so easy to dismiss.  See the work of the psychologist, Nandor Fodor, in that regard.  If odd things do manifest on film, perhaps they can look like a double exposure without being one.  If that statement makes me a "mug," so be it.

comment.author: 9003948@N05
comment._content: If I'd taken this picture myself and knew that I hadn't fiddled it then I'd believe it. But in this case, if there is a possibility that it is a fake - then it's a fake. There is a well documented history of fraudulent 'spirit' pictures and fake spiritualist mumbo-jumbo from around this era. There is no possibility at this distance in time of ever proving that it is genuine. You can only 'believe' it to be genuine. Harry Houdini (who was alive in this era) offered a huge sum of money to any medium he couldn't prove was a fake. He never paid. About this time two little girls in Shipley, Yorkshire, England, cut out pictures of faries from soap packets and took pictures of themselves 'playing' with the 'faries'. Unbelievably they fooled some of the greatest minds of the age who deemed this to be 'evidence' of the existance of faries! Evidence of human gullibilty and wishful thinking more like.......

comment.author: 44300283@N07
comment._content: It was actually pretty common to have a photo done like this in the 19th century. The girl in the middle was most likely the couples daughter,or related in some way. These 'spirit pics' we're meant to pay homage,and keep in contact with lost loved ones. Not only did people think about death in a different way back then,but they took creepy,and wierd pictures about it. So it is a 'real' picture of a ghost,just through double exposure.

comment.author: 8911002@N08
comment._content: I remember learning about these kind of photos in my history of photography class.  This actually used to be a very popular thing to do back in the late 1800s I believe.  The photographer used to take a photo from a past over loved one of a family and add it into the photo.  I don't really remember how they did  it, but if i look up spirit photos from the past I am sure you will get the whole history on it.  Its quite fascinating!  I love it!
